Package org.openftc.easyopencv

Interface OpenCvCamera

All Known Subinterfaces:
OpenCvWebcam
public interface OpenCvCamera

    OpenCvCamera.ViewportRenderer
    The renderer the viewport will use to render the live preview NOTE: this is different than OpenCvCamera.ViewportRenderingPolicy.
    static enum 
    OpenCvCamera.ViewportRenderingPolicy
    The way the viewport will render the live preview IMPORTANT NOTE: The policy you choose here has NO IMPACT on the frames passed to your pipeline.

  • Method Details

    • openCameraDevice

      @Deprecated int openCameraDevice()
      Deprecated.
      Open the connection to the camera device. If the camera is already open, this will not do anything. You must call this before calling: startStreaming(int, int) or startStreaming(int, int, OpenCvCameraRotation) or stopStreaming() See closeCameraDevice()

    • openCameraDeviceAsync

      void openCameraDeviceAsync(OpenCvCamera.AsyncCameraOpenListener cameraOpenListener)
      Performs the same thing as openCameraDevice() except in a non-blocking fashion, with a callback delivered to you when the operation is complete. This can be particularly helpful if using a webcam, as opening/starting streaming on a webcam can be very expensive time-wise. It is reccommended to start streaming from your listener: camera = OpenCvCameraFactory.create.............. camera.setPipeline(new SomePipeline()); camera.openCameraDeviceAsync(new OpenCvCamera.AsyncCameraOpenListener() {
      Parameters:
      cameraOpenListener - the listener to which a callback will be delivered when the camera has been opened

    • closeCameraDevice

      void closeCameraDevice()
      Close the connection to the camera device. If the camera is already closed, this will not do anything.

    • closeCameraDeviceAsync

      void closeCameraDeviceAsync(OpenCvCamera.AsyncCameraCloseListener cameraCloseListener)
      Performs the same this as closeCameraDevice() except in a non-blocking fashion. NOTE: the operation performed in the background thread is synchronized with the main lock, so any calls to camera.XYZ() will block until the callback has been completed.
      Parameters:
      cameraCloseListener - the listener to which a callback will be delivered when the camera has been closed

    • showFpsMeterOnViewport

      void showFpsMeterOnViewport(boolean show)
      If a viewport container ID was passed to the constructor of the implementing class, this method controls whether or not to show some info/statistics on top of the camera feed.
      Parameters:
      show - whether to show some info on top of the camera feed

    • pauseViewport

      void pauseViewport()
      If a viewport container ID was passed to the constructor of the implementing class, this method will "pause" the viewport rendering thread. This can reduce CPU, memory, and power load. For instance, this could be useful if you wish to see the live camera preview as you are initializing your robot, but you no longer require the live preview after you have finished your initialization process. See resumeViewport()

    • resumeViewport

      void resumeViewport()
      If a viewport container ID was passed to the constructor of the implementing class, and the viewport was previously paused by pauseViewport(), this method will "unpause" the viewport rendering thread, so that you can see the live camera feed on the screen again.

    • setViewportRenderingPolicy

      void setViewportRenderingPolicy(OpenCvCamera.ViewportRenderingPolicy policy)
      Set the viewport rendering policy for this camera
      Parameters:
      policy - see OpenCvCamera.ViewportRenderingPolicy

    • setViewportRenderer

      void setViewportRenderer(OpenCvCamera.ViewportRenderer renderer)
      Set the viewport renderer for this camera NOTE: This may ONLY be called if there is not currently a streaming session in flight for this camera.
      Parameters:
      renderer - see OpenCvCamera.ViewportRenderer
      Throws:
      IllegalStateException - if called while a streaming session is in flight

    • startStreaming

      void startStreaming(int width, int height)
      Tell the camera to start streaming images to us! Note that you must make sure the resolution you specify is supported by the camera. If it is not, an exception will be thrown. Keep in mind that the SDK's UVC driver (what OpenCvWebcam uses under the hood) only supports streaming from the webcam in the uncompressed YUV image format. This means that the maximum resolution you can stream at and still get up to 30FPS is 480p (640x480). Streaming at e.g. 720p will limit you to up to 10FPS and so on and so forth. Also see the alternate startStreaming(int, int, OpenCvCameraRotation) method.
      Parameters:
      width - the width of the resolution in which you would like the camera to stream
      height - the height of the resolution in which you would like the camera to stream

    • startStreaming

      void startStreaming(int width, int height, OpenCvCameraRotation rotation)
      Same as startStreaming(int, int) except for:
      Parameters:
      rotation - the rotation that the camera is being used in. This is so that the image from the camera sensor can be rotated such that it is always displayed with the image upright. For a front facing camera, rotation is defined assuming the user is looking at the screen. For a rear facing camera or a webcam, rotation is defined assuming the camera is facing away from the user.

    • stopStreaming

      void stopStreaming()
      Stops streaming images from the camera (and, by extension, stops invoking your vision pipeline), without closing (closeCameraDevice()) the connection to the camera.

    • setPipeline

      void setPipeline(OpenCvPipeline pipeline)
      Specify the image processing pipeline that you wish to be invoked upon receipt of each frame from the camera. Note that switching pipelines on-the-fly (while a streaming session is in flight) *IS* supported.
      Parameters:
      pipeline - the image processing pipeline that you wish to be invoked upon receipt of each frame from the camera.

    • getFrameCount

      int getFrameCount()
      Get the number of frames that have been received from the camera and processed by your pipeline since startStreaming(int, int) was called.
      Returns:
      the number of frames that have been received from the camera and processed by your pipeline since startStreaming(int, int) was called.

    • getFps

      float getFps()
      Get the current frame rate of the overall system (including your pipeline as well as overhead) averaged over the last 30 frames.
      Returns:
      the current frame rate of the overall system (including your pipeline as well as overhead) averaged over the last 30 frames.

    • getPipelineTimeMs

      int getPipelineTimeMs()
      Get the current execution time (in milliseconds) of your pipeline, averaged over the last 30 frames.
      Returns:
      the current execution time (in milliseconds) of your pipeline, averaged over the last 30 frames.

    • getOverheadTimeMs

      int getOverheadTimeMs()
      Get the current system overhead time (in milliseconds) for each frame, averaged over the last 30 frames.
      Returns:
      the current system overhead time (in milliseconds) for each frame, averaged over the last 30 frames

    • getTotalFrameTimeMs

      int getTotalFrameTimeMs()
      Get the current total processing time (in milliseconds) for each frame (including pipeline and overhead), averaged over the last 30 frames.
      Returns:
      the current total processing time (in milliseconds) for each frame (including pipeline and overhead), averaged over the last 30 frames.

    • getCurrentPipelineMaxFps

      int getCurrentPipelineMaxFps()
      Get the current theoretically maximum frame rate that your pipeline (and overhead) could achieve. This is useful for identifying whether or not your pipeline is the bottleneck in the system. For instance, if getFps() reports that the system is running at 10FPS, and this method reported that your theoretical maximum FPS is 12, then your pipeline is the bottleneck. Conversely, if getFps() reported that the system was running at 25FPS, and this method reported that your theoretical maximum FPS is 100, then the camera would be the bottleneck.
      Returns:
      the current theoretically maximum frame rate that your pipeline (and overhead) could achieve.

    • startRecordingPipeline

      void startRecordingPipeline(PipelineRecordingParameters parameters)
      Start recording the output of the camera's current pipeline (If no pipeline is set, then the plain camera image is recorded) A streaming session must be in flight before this can be called. The recording will be automatically stopped when the streaming session is stopped (whether that be manually or automatically at the end of the OpMode), but can also be stopped independently by calling stopRecordingPipeline()
      Parameters:
      parameters - the parameters which define how the recording should done
      Throws:
      IllegalStateException - if called before streaming is started
      IllegalStateException - if recording was started previously

    • stopRecordingPipeline

      void stopRecordingPipeline()
      Stops recording the output of the camera's current pipeline, if a recording session is currently active.
